For any n\geq 1 , let \mathcal {P}_{n} denote the set of all possible types over the alphabet \mathcal {X} with denominator n . That is,

For any type P\in \mathcal {P}_{n} , we can associate the type class T(P) , defined as

\text {given}\ X\sim P,\quad \text {decide between} \quad H_{0}:P=P_{0},\quad \text {versus}\quad H_{1}:P=P_{1}.

In the previous section, we consider the optimal test in the non-asymptotic regime i.e. for finite n what test minimizes the error according to some notion of error. In this section, we ask the question of what is the rate that this error converges to 0. More specifically, if \text {error}_n \leq 2^{-nV} then what is the best (largest) V we can hope to achieve?
Kellen Kanarios202521Information Theory › NP Error Exponent 2025326https://kkanarios32.github.io/006G/006G/006G/Optimal Error Exponent in NP settingDefinition
We say that an error exponent V is achievable with type-1 error \alpha >0 , if there exist a sequence of tests (\Psi _{n}) with errors (\alpha _{n},\beta _{n}) , satisfying
\alpha _{n}\leq \alpha ,\quad \text {and}\quad -\frac {1}{n}\log \beta _{n}\geq V.
Let V_{\alpha }:=\sup \{V:V\text { is achievable with type-1 error }\alpha \} . The optimal error exponent is defined as V^{*}=\inf \{V_{\alpha }:\alpha >0\}=\lim _{\alpha \downarrow 0}V_{\alpha } .
2025326https://kkanarios32.github.io/006H/006H/006H/Stein's LemmaTheorem
For any \alpha >0 , we have V_{\alpha }=D_{KL}(P_{0}\parallel P_{1}) , which also implies that V^{*}=D_{KL}(P_{0}\parallel P_{1}) . In other words, the relative entropy between P_{0} and P_{1} is the optimal type-II error exponent associated with a binary hypothesis testing problem with H_{0}:P_{X}=P_{0} and H_{1}:P_{X}=P_{1} .
Kellen Kanarios202521Information Theory › Bayesian Error Exponent 2025326https://kkanarios32.github.io/006I/006I/006I/Optimal Bayesian Error ExponentDefinition
Consider a binary Bayesian hypothesis testing problem with prior distribution (\pi _{0},\pi _{1}) . Then, we say that an exponent V>0 is achievable, if there exist a sequence of tests \{\Psi _{n}:n\geq 1\} , with probability of errors \{p_{n}(\Psi _{n})=\pi _{0}\psi _{0}(\Psi _{n})+\pi _{1}\psi _{01}(\Psi _{n}):n\geq 1\} , such that
\liminf _{n\to \infty }\frac {1}{n}\log \left (\frac {1}{p_{n}}\right )=\liminf _{n\to \infty }\frac {1}{n}\log \left (\frac {1}{\pi _{0}\psi _{10}(\Psi _{n})+\pi _{1}\psi _{01}(\Psi _{n})}\right )\geq V.
The optimal Bayesian error exponent for binary hypothesis testing with distributions P_{0} and P_{1} is defined as V^{*}\equiv V^{*}(P_{0},P_{1})=\sup \{V>0:V\text {is achievable}\} .
2025326https://kkanarios32.github.io/006J/006J/006J/Optimal Bayesian Error ExponentTheorem
For any \lambda \in [0,1] let P_{\lambda } denote the distribution over \mathcal {X} such that P_{\lambda }(x)\propto P_{0}^{\lambda }(x)\times P_{1}^{\lambda -1}(x) . Then, the optimal error exponent in the Bayesian hypothesis testing problem with distributions P_{0} and P_{1} satisfies:

A discrete probability space cannot contain an infinite sequence of independent events A_1, A_2, \ldots each with probability 1/2. To see this, denote the event space as \mathcal {X}. Note that P(A_1 \cap A_2) + P(A_1 \cap A_2^c) + P(A_1^c \cap A_2) + P(A_1^c \cap A_2^c) = 1 Therefore, every x \in \mathcal {X} must be in one of those four events and have probability at most 1/4. Similarly, we can construct n disjoint sets in the same manner and bound \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) by 1/n. Taking n \to \infty , we have that \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) = 0. Since \mathcal {X} is a discrete probability space, we must have that \sum _{x \in \mathcal {X}} \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) = 1 However, we have just shown that for each x \in \mathcal {X}, \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) = 0. Thus, we have reached a contradiction.
I think my main takeaway from this is that infinite sequences break discrete probability because each discrete event will have probability zero. This is not actually a problem because in an infinite sequence the occurence of any such sequence "feasibly" has zero probability. However, we still want to reason about probabilistic things like the convergence of the average of the sequence. Since discrete probability is broken, we cannot even use it for these things. This is why we need to use measure theory to allow for zero probability sequences, but still provide information about these more "general" events. Who knows if this intuition is right though?

html:ul.html:li: After a bit more digging, the main culprit here is the countable subadditivity condition of measure.

In a discrete probability space, the entire space is at most countable. Therefore, if each individual event has zero probability then the countable union i.e. the whole space will have zero probability.
In measure theoretic probability, we are able to accumulate non-zero probability mass from an uncountable union of zero measure events.
I guess the canonical example of this is that each point on a line has length 0, but the line itself (an uncountable union of points) has non-zero length.
In the dyadic intervals example, each event of an arbitrary discrete probability space can be identified with a point on the line of probability zero.

Guess for english translation: I think what this is saying is that rather than try to define a probability space for a random variable, we can instead just pick probability measures and know that the Simple Random Variable come for free? i.e. (from the book) we can just define a trivial space \Omega = \{1, 0\} and probability measure P(1) = p, P(0) = 1 - p and know that we can get a Bernoulli random variable? In this case X(1) = 1, X(0) = 0 such that P(X = 1) = p and P(X = 0) = 1 - p?

fr:title.text: Notes on Probability and Measure › Expected Value

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Notes on Probability and Measure › Expected Value

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A Simple Random Variable of the form X = \sum _{i} x_i I_{A_i} is assigned expected value as \mathbb {E}[X] = \mathbb {E}\left [\sum _i x_i I_{A_i} \right ] = \sum _i x_i P(A_i) More generally, if f(X) = \sum _i f(x_i) I_{A_i} then \mathbb {E}\left [f(X)\right ] = \sum _i f(x_i) P(A_i) = \sum _x f(x) P[X = x] A useful identity is as follows: \mathbb {E}[X] = \int _0^{\infty } P[X \geq x] \mathrm {d}x
We define the kth moment of X as \mathbb {E}[X^k] = \sum _y y P[X^k = y]
If \exists K such that X_n(\omega ) \leq K for every \omega and n then the X_n are uniformly bounded.
If \{X_n\} is uniformly bounded, and if X = \lim _n X_n with probability 1, then \mathbb {E}[X] = \lim _n \mathbb {E}[X]

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If \phi is a convex function on the range of X then \phi (\mathbb {E}[X]) \leq \mathbb {E}[\phi (X)]

Suppose that \frac {1}{p} + \frac {1}{q} = 1, \quad p > 1,\ q > 1 Then Holder's inequality is \mathbb {E}[XY] \leq \left (\mathbb {E}[|X|^p]\right )^{1/p} \cdot \left (\mathbb {E}[|Y|^q]\right )^{1/q}
